Have you ever tried the bioluminescent lure dance for an Aquanian Glowscale before? I performed this intricate dance three times with this massive Glowscale, and after the third attempt, I finally hooked up to this colossal creature. Wish I had my holo-recorder because it would've made an epic video. Here's the story of how I caught this elusive fish.

We were fishing in the phosphorescent seas of Velluria at the 13th tide, a time when the bioluminescent algae cast an eerie glow across the waves. My brother and I, both seasoned anglers of the Andromeda sector, were hunting for the elusive Glowscales, prized not just for their size but for their shimmering scales that fetch a high price in intergalactic markets.

Our bait? Live humans. They had been abducted from a little planet a few light-years away called Earth. Strapped into lumina-claw harnesses, their terrified movements made the perfect lure, irresistible to the Glowscales. The humans' frantic struggles mimicked the erratic movements of injured prey, drawing the predatory fish from the depths.

I was slow trolling my 1/2oz lumina-claw chatterbait along a crystal reef, its glow amplified by the panicked flailing of the human attached to it. When my lure approached our bio-ship, I noticed a sizable Glowscale trailing it. Instead of reeling it in, I began the bioluminescent lure dance, a series of rapid, erratic movements designed to imitate the frantic, glowing prey of the Glowscale. It pursued for a while before vanishing into the depths.

Frustrated but undeterred, I cast back toward the same crystal reef. As my lure neared the ship again, a Glowscale darted from underneath and lunged at my bait. It missed, so I performed the lure dance again, flicking the lure side to side, creating a mesmerizing light show. The human bait screamed, their voice muffled by the vacuum suit, adding an eerie undertone to the lure's glow. The Glowscale missed again and retreated beneath the ship. I thought to myself, could it be the same Glowscale from earlier?

I cast right next to the ship to see if it would strike again, but it never resurfaced. So I aimed at the crystal reef once more. As my lure came close to the ship, the Glowscale reappeared, missed the bait again, and I did the lure dance once more. It missed a second time. By now, I was super frustrated! This was the third time it evaded capture.

The Glowscale was using the shadow of the bio-ship to ambush any bioluminescent prey that swam by. Knowing it wouldn't strike at close range, I made another cast. As my lure approached the ship, the Glowscale swam out from underneath again. This time, I was ready. Before it could strike, I started the lure dance right away. After a few dazzling moves, "Zap". I finally hooked it.

Not realizing its true size until I had it hooked, I took it slow. My brother activated the netfield, and we secured it. I looked at him with joy and relief because this Glowscale had been stressing me out. After so many tries, the effort finally paid off.

We stored the Glowscale in the bio-hold, its scales shimmering under the containment lights. As we prepared to head back, I couldn't help but think about the tiny planet these humans came from. Earth, they called it. A place teeming with life, now a hunting ground for the galaxy's most dangerous sport.

Back on the ship, my brother and I discussed the ethics of our bait. "It's not like they know," he said, "besides, their numbers are in the billions. A few won't be missed."

I wasn't so sure. Each human we used seemed to have its own personality, its own fear and desperation. They were more than just bait‚Äîthey were sentient beings with lives of their own. Their terror was palpable, their eyes pleading for mercy as they were dragged into the depths.

We entered the coordinates for our home base and engaged the warp drive. As the stars stretched into lines and we sped through the cosmos, I couldn't shake the feeling of guilt. The Glowscale we caught was magnificent, a true trophy, but at what cost? The thought of the humans, their planet, and our role in their abduction weighed heavily on my mind.

In the end, I resolved to find another way to catch Glowscales, a method that didn't involve sentient beings. But for now, I had to live with the knowledge of what I'd done, and the haunting memories of those terrified humans, their faces etched into my memory forever.

I am a physicist and I explain why current physics leaves not room for the possibility that brain processes can be a sufficient condition for the existence of consciousness. The hypothesis that consciousness emerges from, or can be identified with physical, chemical or biological processes is incompatible with current physics.
It is a scientifically established fact that a mental experience is associated with numerous distinct microscopic physical processes that occur at different points; there is no physical entity that connects all these distinct microscopic processes, therefore the existence of mental experience requires an element of connection that is not described by current physics. This missing element of connection can be identified with what we traditionally refer to as the soul (in my youtube channel you can find a video with more detailed explanations). 

Emergent properties are often thought of as arising from complex systems (like the brain). However, I argue that these properties are subjective cognitive constructs that depend on the level of abstraction we choose to analyze and describe the system. Since these descriptions are mind-dependent, consciousness, being implied by these cognitive contructs, cannot itself be an emergent property. 

Preliminary considerations: the concept of set refers to something that has an intrinsically conceptual and subjective nature and implies the arbitrary choice of determining which elements are to be included in the set; what can exist objectively are only the individual elements. Defining a set is like drawing an imaginary line to separate some elements from others. This line doesn't exist physically; it‚Äôs a mental construct. The same applies to sequences of processes‚Äîthey are abstract concepts created by our minds. 

Mental experiences are necessary for the existence of subjectivity/arbitrariness and cognitive constructs; Therefore, mental experience itself cannot be just a cognitive construct. 
Obviously we can conceive the concept of consciousness, but the concept of consciousness is not actual consciousness; We can talk about consciousness or about pain, but merely talking about it isn‚Äôt the same as experiencing it. (With the word consciousness I do not refer to self-awareness, but to the property of being conscious= having a mental experiences such as sensations, emotions, thoughts, memories and even dreams)

From the above considerations it follows that only indivisible elements may exist objectively and independently of consciousness, and consequently the only logically coherent and significant statement is that consciousness exists as a property of an indivisible element. Furthermore, this indivisible entity must interact globally with brain processes because there is a well-known correlation between brain processes and consciousness. However, this indivisible entity cannot be physical, since according to the laws of physics, there is no physical entity with such properties. The soul is the missing element that interprets globally the distinct elementary physical processes occurring at separate points in the brain as a unified mental experience. 

Clarifications

The brain itself doesn't exist as a completely mind-independent entity. The concept of the brain is based on separating a group of quantum particles from everything else, which is a subjective process, not dictated purely by the laws of physics. Actually there is a continuous exchange of molecules with the blood and when and how such molecules start and stop being part of the brain is decided arbitrarily. An example may clarify this point: the concept of nation. Nation is not a physical entity and does not refer to a mind-independent entity because it is just a set of arbitrarily chosen people. The same goes for the brain.  

Brain processes consist of many parallel sequences of ordinary elementary physical processes occurring at separate points. There is no direct connection between the separate points in the brain and such connections are just a subjective abstractions used to approximately describe sequences of many distinct physical processes. Indeed, considering consciousness as a property of an entire sequence of elementary processes implies the arbitrary definition of the entire sequence; the entire sequence as a whole (and therefore every function/property/capacity attributed to the brain) is a subjective abstraction that does not refer to any mind-independendent reality. 

Physicalism/naturalism is based on the belief that consciousness is an emergent property of the brain. However, an emergent property is defined as a property that is possessed by a set of elements that its individual components do not possess; my arguments prove that this definition implies that emergent properties are only subjective cognitive constructs and therefore, consciousness cannot be an emergent property.   Actually, emergent properties are just simplified and approximate descriptions or subjective classifications of underlying physical processes or properties, which are described directly by the fundamental laws of physics alone, without involving any emergent properties (arbitrariness/subjectivity is involved when more than one option/description is possible). An approximate description is only an abstract idea, and no actual entity exists per se corresponding to that approximate description, simply because an actual entity is exactly what it is and not an approximation of itself. What physically exists are the underlying physical processes. Emergence is nothing more than a cognitive construct that is applied to physical phenomena, and cognition itself can only come from a mind; thus emergence can never explain mental experience as, by itself, it implies mental experience. 

Conclusions 

My approach is based on scientific knowledge of the brain's physical processes. My arguments show that physicalism is incompatible with the very foundations of scientific knowledge because current scientific understanding of molecular processes excludes the possibility that brain processes alone can account for the existence of consciousness. 
An indivisible non-physical element must exist as a necessary condition for the existence of consciousness because mental experiences are linked to many distinct physical processes occurring at different points; it is therefore necessary for all these distinct processes to be interpreted collectively by a mind-independent element, and a mind-independent element can only be intrinsically indivisible because it cannot depend on subjectivity. This indivisible element cannot be physical because the laws of physics do not describe any physical entity with the required properties.

This perspective unifies various phenomena, from quantum mechanics to cosmology, by suggesting that consciousness creates and integrates information, forming the fabric of reality.

Consciousness as a Fundamental Field
Consciousness is not just an observer but an active creator of information, collapsing infinite possibilities into specific realities. This process resembles the quantum mechanical concept of wavefunction collapse, where observation selects a particular state from a range of possibilities.

Space and Time
Space: Space can be understood as the structure formed by the interconnected nodes of information created and integrated by consciousness. The distance between objects is a measure of the information required to transition from one state to another, making space a fabric woven by the integration of information at different points.

Time: Time arises from the continuous process of information integration. It is not an independent dimension but a dynamic process that emerges as consciousness integrates information, creating a sequence of events. The rate of this integration determines the flow of time.

Patterns and Harmony

These patterns, found in both micro (biological structures) and macro (cosmic structures) scales, demonstrate the universal drive towards symmetry and order.

Entropy and Complexity
As consciousness integrates more information, the complexity of the entanglement network increases, leading to higher entropy. However, consciousness also seeks to maintain harmony, resulting in a dynamic balance between growth (increasing complexity) and symmetry.

Subjective Experience and Perception of Time
The rate of information integration in the brain affects our subjective experience of time. High cognitive load (being busy) leads to rapid information integration, making time feel like it‚Äôs flying. Low cognitive load (boredom) results in slower information integration, making time drag.

Supporting Studies
Transfer Entropy and Information Flow: Studies using transfer entropy to measure directional information flow in complex systems support the idea that increasing complexity corresponds to higher rates of information integration. This method is applied to systems such as neural networks and financial markets, illustrating how information transfer underlies complex behaviors.

Causal Emergence: Research on causal emergence shows how new macroscopic properties arise from interactions within a system, reinforcing the view that consciousness integrates and organizes information in increasingly complex ways.

Information Theory in Complex Systems: Shannon information theory applied to complex systems demonstrates how entropy and complexity are linked through information processing. These studies emphasize the role of information flow and integration in understanding the dynamics and evolution of complex systems.

Conclusion
By framing consciousness as both the creator and observer of information, my theory provides a rich, interconnected framework for understanding space and time as fundamental aspects of the universe. This dynamic equilibrium, where increasing complexity (entropy) is balanced by the drive for harmony and symmetry, offers a holistic view of reality.
